image.altText: woman takes selfie with a highland cow

props.synopsis: Tasmania recorded its highest number of visitors for the June quarter on record — but what attracts tourists to a colder climate?

title.children: Tasmania so cool right now with tourists numbers up

image.altText: Crew preparing to shoot in WA town of Gracetown during the first week of filming of Drift.

props.synopsis: With promised local content requirements for streaming services delayed indefinitely, Australian filmmakers say the local industry is hurting.

title.children: 'Destroying aspirations': Filmmakers still waiting on content quotas

image.altText: Cash inside a shopping bag on a desk.

props.synopsis: As part of a months-long investigation, officers from Tasmania Police, Australian Federal Police and Australian Border Force, intercepted the man and allegedly found $580,000 cash in several sealed plastic bags in a supermarket-branded cooler bag.

title.children: Man arrested with $580k in grocery bag amid months-long police operation

image.altText: A spit of land and beach and the mouth of a bay seen from the air.

props.synopsis: A 100-turbine wind farm, the largest in Tasmania, will be built on Robbins Island in north-west Tasmania following seven delays to the decision, and multiple court appeals over concerns for migratory birds.

title.children: Robbins Island wind farm approved after years of delays

image.altText: View of a cruise ship in Antarctic environment, with tourists in several boats near the ship.

props.synopsis: More than 100,000 international tourists — including almost 10,000 Australians — travel to Antarctica each year. But a new study shows that getting there creates a significant carbon footprint.

title.children: Antarctica is a growing tourist hotspot. But getting there comes at a cost

image.altText: A prison corridor taken through a barred hallway.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's child safety regulator is inquiring into concerns that prisoners who have offended against children could — until recently — be employed at the state's reception prisons.

title.children: Reception prisons to stop hiring prisoners with child abuse convictions

image.altText: silhouette of a man holding an upside down flag with red background, union jack and white southern cross stars

props.synopsis: "Sovereign citizens" believe Australian laws do not apply to them. That's where pseudolaw comes in.

title.children: 'I do not consent': How pseudolaw supports 'sovcit' ideas

image.altText: Andriy Parubiy sitting in a red chair at a microphoned desk.

props.synopsis: Former Ukrainian parliamentary speaker Andriy Parubiy has been killed in the western city of Lviv, and a manhunt is underway for his killer.

title.children: Former Ukrainian parliament speaker shot dead in 'horrific murder'

image.altText: A soldier in a trench, firing a gun, while another soldier looks on behind holding a grenade.

props.synopsis: Australian troops are among a group of allies helping train Ukrainian soldiers in England. Despite technological advances in war, sometimes it's about getting back to basics.

title.children: Amid Russia's invasion, some Ukrainians have to 'fight like it's the 1940s'

image.altText: serena williams injects herself in the arm

props.synopsis: As elite athletes, celebrities and influencers sign on to sell weight-loss drugs, experts say our obsession with losing weight is getting more and more dangerous.

title.children: Serena Williams is promoting weight-loss drugs. Experts are worried

image.altText: A man and woman embrace on the verandah of a weatherboard house

props.synopsis: In the aftermath of two police officers' deaths, the tiny Victorian town of Porepunkah finds itself grappling with an unwelcome transformation: from peaceful mountain gateway to the epicentre of a manhunt that has gripped the nation.

title.children: From Snowtown to Leongatha, how tragedy can redefine a town

image.altText: Max Gawn of the Demons competes with Lloyd Meek of the Hawks for the AFL ball in a ball-up

props.synopsis: Predicting who is going to win during each round of the AFL is tough, and even computer algorithms struggle to do better than the luckiest human.

title.children: Why predicting winners in the footy is a lot harder than we think

image.altText: A montage of an old two-storey stone mansion, a rolls-royce car, a sheep and a boy wearing a VR eyemask.

props.synopsis: The drought in western Victoria is forcing sheep farmers to the wall, but amid the dirt and dust are green shoots of optimism and ingenuity that will change farming here forever.

title.children: Farmers innovate to beat drought in former 'wool capital of the world'

image.altText: The lower half of two standing people. One person has swollen and bandaged feet.

props.synopsis: Queensland hospitals have reported being overwhelmed with patients suffering from respiratory illnesses as experts sound the alarm about growing vaccine mistrust.

title.children: RATs are potentially skewing official case numbers this flu season

image.altText: Nic Naitanui, Matt Priddis, Dean Cox, Mitchell Brown and Scott Lycett stand arm in arm singing West Coast Eagles' AFL team song.

props.synopsis: Mitch Brown will forever be etched in the game's history, but experts, advocacy groups and fans pushing for systematic change say this is not a time for celebration.

title.children: AFL's homophobic culture is 'deeply embedded' in the sport

image.altText: Australian F1 driver Oscar Piastri taks a corner in his McLaren car during qualifying for a grand prix.

props.synopsis: Australia's Oscar Piastri is starting from pole position ahead of teammate Lando Norris at the Dutch Grand Prix at Zandvoort. Here's what you need to know about the race.

title.children: What time does the F1 Dutch Grand Prix start? How can I watch?

image.altText: Japan's Naomi Osaka (R) stands at the net shaking hands with Australia's Daria Kasatkina after their US Open match.

props.synopsis: Australia's last entrant in the women's US Open draw, Daria Kasatkina, takes two-time Flushing Meadows champion Naomi Osaka to three sets before bowing out, setting up a clash between Osaka and American star Coco Gauff.

title.children: Osaka ends Kasatkina's US Open run to set up Gauff blockbuster

image.altText: Runners on a road

props.synopsis: An estimated 35,000 participants are taking part in the Sydney Marathon today, with this year's race marking the city's first under the Abbott World Marathon Majors series.

title.children: Thousands take to the streets for iconic Sydney Marathon

image.altText: A group of people holding red and white flags with a fire in the background.

props.synopsis: The building was set alight on Friday night which caused the area to turn an eerie orange colour.

title.children: Three dead after angry mob sets fire to parliament building in Indonesia

image.altText: Woman with dark hair looking serious

props.synopsis: After 45 minutes of false suspense, Thailand's constitutional court did exactly what was expected. Her dismissal flings the country into political instability.

title.children: Shinawatra's dismissal highlights limits of Thailand's fledgling democracy

image.altText: Reece Walsh throws a pass off the ground in a Brisbane Broncos NRL game.

props.synopsis: The Brisbane Broncos climb into the top four heading into the final round of the NRL season after beating North Queensland 38-30 in Townsville.

title.children: Broncos climb into top four despite schoolboy errors in 'bizarre game'

image.altText: Tom Gleeson on the set of Hard Quiz gesturing behind him with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: Another week, another opportunity to show us your substandard trivia skills. Too mean? Too bad.

title.children: Convinced you can nail this quiz? Be my guest

image.altText: A woman with red hair across her face kneels down in the street. She wears a yellow dress.

props.synopsis: Dozens of high-quality releases from all genres hit the shelves/streaming services in August, giving us a nasty case of choice paralysis. We've covered 10 of the month's finest albums, covering hip hop, indie rock, neo-soul, electro, pop and more.

title.children: The 10 albums we couldn't stop listening to in August

image.altText: A woman and man holding on to wheelie bin handles next to a pile of coffee grounds.

props.synopsis: Melbourne's love affair with coffee is causing thousands of tonnes of ground coffee waste — leading to methane emissions. One social enterprise is tackling this, combining it with animal waste — another large emitter — to improve sustainability.

title.children: How grounds from your morning coffee are helping to reduce emissions

image.altText: A close-up of man's hand holding a canister labelled as "pepper spray" in each hand. A couple of other bottles on the table.

props.synopsis: From Monday, September 1, Northern Territory residents can buy and use pepper spray for personal protection in a 12-month trial by the NT government. Let's break down the rules.

title.children: Want to buy pepper spray in NT? Here's what you need to know

image.altText: Three women in pink shirts, jeans and chaps with their hands infront of them standing infront of a car in a red dirt arena.

props.synopsis: Sidelined in the sport's history by the words "women don't do that", female bronc riders are proving they not only do it but do it thrillingly well — and the sport is taking notice.

title.children: Outback women don't shy from one of the world's most dangerous sports

image.altText: Isabelle Kelly holds a towel to her mouth after an injury in a Sydney Roosters NRLW game.

props.synopsis: Roosters captain Isabelle Kelly's season appears over after she was hospitalised for a distressing jaw injury in the team' 15th straight NRLW win.

title.children: Isabelle Kelly suffers ugly jaw injury in Roosters' 15th straight win

image.altText: Man wearing suit and black frame glasses looks on.

props.synopsis: Australia will pay a further $70 million per year to cover the ongoing resettlement costs for the group of more than 350 people.

title.children: Burke signs $400m deal to deport hundreds of former detainees to Nauru

image.altText: Linda wears black rimmed glasses and a blue blazer as she smiles

props.synopsis: Former WA senator Linda Reynolds has called on Prime Minister Anthony Albanese to apologise for the government's handling of the alleged rape of her former staffer, after what she described as four-and-a-half years of "hell".

title.children: Former WA senator Linda Reynolds demands apology from PM over Brittany Higgins

image.altText: Volunteers group

props.synopsis: Many people don't want to become long-term volunteers, Yolandi Vermaak realised. So she came up with a new system to allow people to get involved and save the wombats.

title.children: The volunteers fighting to save wombats, one burrow at a time

image.altText: Two knights fighting

props.synopsis: An increasing number of women are pulling on up to 40 kilograms of steel armour to take part in historic medieval combat.

title.children: Fighting like a knight 'extremely freeing' as all-female teams grow

image.altText: A hand squeezes Endota natural zinc sunscreen from a tube.

props.synopsis: Five of seven sunscreens "paused" from sale on the Australian market this week due to concerns over their sun protection claims, share the same base formula, according to analysis by leading sunscreen experts.

title.children: Sunscreens 'paused' from sale share same base formula, analysis reveals

image.altText: maclean brothers hold scottish and australian flag after arriving at cairns after 139 at sea

props.synopsis: After 139 days at sea, three Scottish brothers have set a new world record by completing the first and fastest unsupported row across the Pacific Ocean.

title.children: Scottish brothers finish mammoth row across Pacific Ocean
